title: Adrenal Incidentaloma with Subclinical Cushing Syndrome
setup_script: A 50-year-old woman undergoes abdominal CT for renal colic, revealing a 4 cm right adrenal mass. She has mild hypertension and obesity. Workup shows elevated late-night salivary cortisol and failure to suppress on 1 mg overnight dexamethasone test, consistent with subclinical Cushing syndrome.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Explain differential of adrenal incidentaloma: benign adenoma, pheochromocytoma, cortisol or aldosterone-secreting tumor, malignancy.
Order hormonal evaluation: dexamethasone suppression test, plasma metanephrines, aldosterone/renin ratio, and DHEAS.
Review imaging characteristics: size, Hounsfield units, washout on CT or MRI to assess risk of malignancy.
Discuss criteria for adrenalectomy: size >4 cm, growth over time, functional tumors, or suspicious imaging features.
Counsel patient on risks and benefits of laparoscopic adrenalectomy versus observation; consider comorbid conditions.
Optimize blood pressure and control hypercortisolism preoperatively with medical therapy if severe.
Perform laparoscopic right adrenalectomy with attention to vascular control and avoiding tumor rupture.
Anticipate need for perioperative steroid coverage due to suppressed contralateral adrenal gland; taper gradually postoperatively.
Assess final pathology for adenoma versus carcinoma; check Weiss criteria for malignancy.
Monitor postoperative cortisol levels and signs of adrenal insufficiency; adjust steroid replacement accordingly.
Arrange endocrinology follow-up for long-term management of blood pressure and metabolic syndrome.
Plan surveillance imaging to monitor for recurrence or growth of contralateral nodules.

critical_decision_points: Comprehensive hormonal evaluation of incidentaloma to determine functionality.
Using imaging criteria and size to decide surgery versus observation.
Safe laparoscopic adrenalectomy and avoidance of tumor spillage.
Perioperative steroid management to prevent adrenal crisis.
Long-term surveillance for recurrence and metabolic effects.
